node.text:
Had a quick chat with Alexis @whataboutbunny this morning to get pumped for my virtual book event tomorrow!
•
Swipe up in my stories or click the link in my bio to register for the event (it’s free)! You can check my “shop local” story highlight to purchase a copy of my book from one of the awesome indie stores hosting the event 📚 
•
Can’t wait to chat about How Stella Learned to Talk, answer questions (comment your questions below!), and share stories about our talking dogs. See you all there!
•
#howstellalearnedtotalk #stellabook #bookevent #booklaunch #hunger4words #newbook #talkingdog

node.text:
I talk about this a lot in my book, but I wanted to show that it’s okay if you can’t say “yes” every time your dog requests something. Responding “no,” “later,” or “all done” can help your dog understand the meanings of those concepts, and will show her how SHE can also say those words!
 •
In this video, after I used her board to say “outside later,” Stella walked away and laid in the other room. Using Stella’s board combined with my verbal speech allows her to better understand my words. Even when your AAC user talks independently, remember to keep modeling and talking with their device!
•
#hunger4words #talkingdog #aac #corewords #slp

node.title: “Do I have to say ‘yes’ every time my dog requests something?”

node.text:
Here is a recent dispute between Stella and me. I brought home a new bag of treats and gave her a couple to try. She absolutely loved them and had been continuously requesting more!

Stella said “come eat” and I responded that we were all done and she would eat later. Stella whined, barked, and stomped her paws. After I narrated “Stella is mad” a couple of times, she whined, said “bye,” and barked, sending me out of the room.

A few minutes later, she came to find me again and we carried on with our afternoon.

node.text:
How Stella Learned to Talk is about more than Stella. It’s an invitation to look at our pets from a new perspective, a call to follow your curiosities, and the beginning of a new era of interspecies communication.
•
You can pre-order your copy by clicking the link in my bio! Thank you all so much for your continued outpouring of support. I cannot wait for May 4th!
•
#hunger4words #howstellalearnedtotalk #stellabook #book #talkingdog

node.text:
“Outside” is without a doubt Stella’s most frequently used word. We hear a combination of “outside,” “come outside,” “want outside” and “play outside” at least 20 times per day.
•
Often times after she has exhausted all of her routine phrases to say she wants to go outside, Stella gets creative, like she did in this video. When Stella said “outside,” I tried seeing if she would play with her toy inside instead. But she did not. She responded by saying “come come come leash,” demonstrating yet another way to clarify her message and tell me she wanted to head outside.
•
Seeing this level of flexibility with her vocabulary is very impressive to me. Stella doesn’t just understand one way to convey certain messages, she thinks of new ways to express the same messages on the spot 🧠🐶✨
•
#hunger4words #outside

node.text:
Back when we stayed the night in an Airbnb, Stella was ready to leave first thing in the morning.
•
Stella said “want bye” then waited by the door. After both Jake and I told her a few times that we would leave soon, she told us “want bye” again.
•
Stella’s commitment to her desires has always been inspiring to me. It seems that when she feels she wasn’t understood or didn’t get the reaction she was expecting, she either repeats the exact same message or tries to say the same concept in a slightly different way, which is such a great social skill.
•
#hunger4words

node.text:
Observe, wait, listen is a popular speech therapy strategy from @thehanencentre . First, we observe a child’s body language to see what she might be trying to communicate. Then, we wait. We stay silent, creating the opportunity for the child to respond or use words to share her thoughts. Finally, we fully listen to the message and respond appropriately.
•
This strategy works incredibly well with Stella too! In this video, after I modeled some specific types of play Stella might have wanted, I observed Stella’s body language. She sniffed / looked into her toy bin, then pawed at the cabinet where we keep her treats. Jake opened the cabinet, Stella sniffed her treats, and then she said, “Yes want eat.” If I would have jumped in to talk for her when I saw her sniffing the cabinet, I would have taken away her opportunity to speak for herself.
•
Being comfortable with waiting and silence is a HUGE part of teaching language! I’ve found that the more space I give Stella to explore her words and communicate independently, the more frequently she shares her voice.
•
#hunger4words

node.text:
While I was in the middle of rearranging the cabinet where we keep the Kong and treats we give her when we leave, Stella said “bye bye” then “bed come eat.” (You’ll hear a random “play” in there from a button malfunction that day). Stella thought we were leaving and she’d get to enjoy her treat in her bed.
•
I told Stella we weren’t leaving, and she responded with a plan B for getting a treat: “Stella good Stella.” I couldn’t resist such a strong negotiation!
•
Stella’s ability to understand my response, then change her strategy to ask in a different way is incredible! As always, Stella’s thoughts and reasonings are much more complex than I ever would have imagined.
•
#hunger4words

node.title: Stella is a very good girl!

node.text:
In the morning while we were waiting for Jake to get up, Stella said “help help come.” After I walked over and scratched her, she commented “come good” and requested “water.” I knew Stella had a full water dish, so I took it to mean the water at the beach. I told Stella we would play in the water at the beach later. Stella responded “happy outside.”
•
I scratched Stella for awhile until we heard Jake stirring. After he got up, Stella peeked around the corner, saw that he was up, and came back to confirm to me that he was off the bed by saying “off is off.” I provided an expansion of her utterance by saying, “Jake is off bed” to model a more complex sentence.
•
Then, Stella requested “outside.” I told her that Jake was coming, and he would take her out later. Stella said “now” then laid down by her board to wait for him. When Jake took Stella to the beach a few minutes later, she had a blast swimming after her water toy!
•
Such long conversations like these don’t happen every day. But when they do, they are truly incredible to witness and be a part of.
•
#hunger4words

node.text:
Happy International Dog Day to this smart girl who speaks up for herself! I love everything Stella has to say...even when she lets us know she doesn’t want to hangout right now 🙃
•
When Jake and I kept calling Stella over, she didn’t come right away. Eventually, she came over to say “Stella later Stella Stella yes” before she walked back to lay down on the other side of the room. Even Stella needs her alone time!
•
#internationaldogday #hunger4words

node.text:
After Stella was standing in front of her device and staring at me, she said “water want.” When I said her phrase “water want” back to her, Stella licked her lips and watched me as I walked over to her water bowl. I refilled her bowl, and Stella got a drink 🐶💦
•
Knowing that Stella can functionally communicate her basic needs gives me so much peace of mind. If I don’t notice that Stella’s water bowl is empty right away, I can always count on this smart girl to let me know!

node.text:
Every morning after I get up and make coffee, Stella comes out to the living room and we talk together. This is always one of my favorite times of the day!
•
Stella tells me what she wants to do, or where she wants to go, or how she’s feeling. I love listening to her, and understanding what’s going through her mind.
•
In this video, Stella told me “yes park.” I told Stella we were waiting for Jake to finish getting ready, and she responded “mad look.” When Jake opened the door, Stella said “yes,” then greeted him with her happy gestures: ears back and tail wagging. She was excited to see Jake and head to the park!
•
#hunger4words

node.title: A stellar start to the day 🌟

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Christina Hunger, MA, CCC-SLP on July 27, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'hunger fwords words Tip Of The Week Focus on all the ways your dog is progressing @hunger4words'.

node.text:
In my book, I talk a lot about celebrating the small victories in speech therapy and in Stella’s communication journey as well. Progress takes time and isn’t always easy to spot, especially if you’re not sure what you’re looking for!
•
Here are some common signs of progress that may be easy to miss:

Your dog is…

-“Babbling” with the buttons (pushing different buttons “randomly” and exploring them). This typically comes before understanding what each different word says and means.
-Watching you use the buttons 
-Looking down at a button
-Looking down at a button then up to you
-Barking at the button
-Playing with the button 
-Whining near a button
-Circling around a button or the board 
-Nudging a button
•
All of these are signs of progress because they show awareness and interest in the device. Get excited when you see your dog doing any of these things! Awareness is the foundation. It leads to understanding, then use!
•
#hunger4words #tipoftheweek #dogaac #believeinpotential #talkingdog #talkingdogbuttons

node.text:
Stella likes to eat outside sometimes!
•
After we were hanging out in our yard for awhile in the evening, Stella started whining a bunch. I tried playing different toys with her, but she wasn’t interested. I tried bringing her inside, but she refused. So, I brought her board out to see what she had to say.
•
As soon as I set her board down, Stella licked my face repeatedly. This is often her reaction when I bring her board somewhere new for her! Then Stella immediately said, “outside come eat.”
•
I brought Stella’s dinner outside, she ate it up, and continued happily playing in the yard 🐶😊
•
#hunger4words #stella #talkingdog #talkingdogbuttons #dogaac

node.text:
Thank you so much @forbes and @j9_maclachlan for highlighting me and my work with Stella as an example of innovation! 💡🎉 
•
To me, my story of teaching Stella to talk was always so much deeper than what she was able to learn and communicate. It’s also the story of following a curiosity, living my passion, and opening up a whole new world to explore.
•
Thank you again @forbes @j9_maclachlan! This was such a fun surprise for me to read!

Photo by Christina Hunger, MA, CCC-SLP on July 20, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'words Tip Of The Week Find a good "home" for your dog's buttons @hunger4words'.

node.text:
Making sure your buttons or board are easy for both you AND your dog to use make a huge difference! Jake, Stella, and I have lived in 5 different homes together. In each new space, we’ve trialed Stella’s board in different spots to see where it’s the easiest for all of us to use. The more convenient the location, the more we model words, and the more opportunities Stella has to use them!
•
The most successful spots for us to have her board have always been in places that:
-are free of clutter 
-have open space around it for Stella to approach it comfortably
-we all naturally hangout in
-are central enough so we can hear the buttons from other rooms
- are in natural walking paths to Stella’s routine activities 
•
Feel free to go through your own trial period and see how different locations impact your family’s use of the buttons!
•
#hunger4words #tipoftheweek #dogaac #talkingdog

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Christina Hunger, MA, CCC-SLP on July 13, 2021. May be a cartoon of text that says 'b forords Tip Of The Week Model the next level of language development @hunger4words'.

node.text:
In speech therapy, we spend time talking to our clients one level above their current expressive abilities to model the next stage for them to reach in their development. I use the same strategy with Stella!
•
If your dog hasn’t started using words yet, use single words to narrate their activities (e.g. “outside,” “come,” “play,” “eat,” “walk”). 
•
If your dog is using single words, start talking in two-word phrases often (e.g. “Stella eat,” “Stella play,” “Come outside”, “Walk now”).
•
When your dog starts making two-word phrases, bump up your modeling to three-word phrases. (e.g. “Stella come outside,” “Stella eat now,” “Come play outside,” “Walk outside now”) …and so on.
•
Language development is gradual! Expect to see your dog spending time in each stage before progressing on to the next one.
•
#hunger4words #tipoftheweek #talkingdog #dogaac #languagedevelopment #speechtherapy

node.text:
“Play outside” has been the anthem of our summer!
•
When Stella finished eating, I asked her what she wanted to do next. She responded “play outside” immediately and headed straight toward the door as soon as I said “yes!”
•
No matter how many walks we take, how long we spend in our yard, or how many new parks we visit, we still hear “play outside” several times a day. Stella is thoroughly enjoying having a yard to play in! 🐶🎾
•
#hunger4words #talkingdog #stella #play #outside #buttontraining #dogaac

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Christina Hunger, MA, CCC-SLP on July 06, 2021. May be a cartoon of text that says 'hunger words Tip Of The Week Build off of your dog's strengths @hunger4words'.

node.text:
**Introducing “The Tip of the Week”! Each week I want to share with you a suggestion for strengthening your communication with your pet. Let me know in the comments what thoughts you have about this week’s tip! 😊**
•

When you’re teaching your dog how to use words, really think about how your dog already communicates well with you, or when your dog communicates the most frequently.
•
Instead of targeting brand new communication functions with a system that is brand new to your dog, start by introducing concepts she’s already familiar with and is already communicating about in some way. When we focus on existing strengths and build from that foundation, we see the most growth and success!
•
If your dog is already using words and you’re trying to decide what to add next, think about the words she uses most frequently or most “successfully.” Are there any others you could add to help her talk about those experiences more? Which words would combine well with the words she’s already using? Recognize her strengths and build from there!
•
#hunger4words #tipoftheweek #talkingdog #aac #languagedevelopment #dogaac #buttontraining

node.text:
Stella finds a baby opossum…!
•
This morning while I was sitting outside drinking coffee, Stella was roaming around our yard. I heard her barking from the back corner that’s completely covered with bushes, so I walked over to see what was happening. I peered through the branches to see Stella standing right over a young, alive opossum 😳
•
I mentally panicked. I couldn’t fit through the bushes to grab Stella, and I know she has a very strong, innate hunting drive. I was scared of what I might see happen next if I couldn’t physically intervene.
•
I firmly and calmly said, “Stella leave it.” Stella looked up to me, and I continued repeating “leave it, leave it, leave it” while locking eyes with Stella. Stella stayed completely still. After about 15 seconds, the opossum slowly stood up and started inching away, right in between Stella and me.
•
As soon as the opossum reached the fence and slipped through to the other side, I shouted “YES STELLA!! Good girl!!” Stella bolted out of the bushes to me, jumped around in circles, and wagged her tail. We celebrated together and went back inside. Stella ran to her board, SAID “GOOD,” wagged her tail, and rolled over for a belly rub 😭 She knew how good of a girl she was.
•
Saying I’m proud of Stella is a complete understatement. I am truly in awe of her. Stella listened to my words and let a wild animal walk away right in front of her eyes. On top of that, she commented on her own behavior, recognizing that she was so “good” 💜
•
Communication changes us. It allows us to not just act from instinct, but to listen, think, and intentionally choose what to do next. When we focus on building solid lines of communication, we are opening the door to a more thoughtful, understanding, and connected world.

node.text:
Perfect opportunity to model words!
•
I often talk about how the best time to model words is during naturalistic contexts, and when you see your dog already communicating. Here’s what that looks like in practice!
•
Stella’s ball rolled under the plant stand. She stared at it, barked at it, and looked at me. Her communication was clear- she needed help getting her ball out. I pointed to the ball, and said “ball” to acknowledge that I saw what Stella was trying to show me. Then I modeled “help ball” on her board, and retrieved the ball for her.
•
When children are learning to talk, we all do the same thing (sometimes without even realizing it)! We notice their gestures or vocalizations, attach meaning to them, and model the words that go with the concepts they’re already communicating.
•
By modeling words in natural contexts like these, we are acknowledging and responding to all forms of communication.  We’re teaching during meaningful situations, and are showing our learners another way they can express their thoughts when gestures alone aren’t enough, or aren’t working for them.
•
Spending even just a few focused minutes a day on your dog’s communication can really go a long way in their learning!
•
#hunger4words #stella #talkingdog #aac #dogaac #modelinglanguage #languagedevelopment

node.text:
Who’s the one keeping our household running right on schedule....? STELLA!
•
This video was taken about 20 minutes later than when we usually take her out in the morning ⏰ Stella walked to her board and said, “No outside. Come outside.”
•
I love how Stella first identified what had not yet happened, then let us know what to do about it. By pointing out that we hadn’t gone outside, it seemed like she was trying to explain or justify her desires, just like we all do when trying to persuade someone of something. Seeing these patterns in Stella’s communication makes me wonder if she’s giving simple rationales? Is Stella going beyond expressing what she wants, and also saying WHY she wants it? Is Stella trying to explain her reasoning with the limited vocabulary she has available?
•
To me, this is the most fun part about this journey- observing patterns in Stella’s communication, reflecting on what’s happening, and wondering even more about her potential ✨
•
#hunger4words #talkingdog #aac #interspeciescommunication #howstellalearnedtotalk #stella #believeinpotential

node.text:
When we listen to Stella, she listens to us!
•
I talk about this concept a lot in my book. Early on in Stella’s learning, I realized that just like with children, the more we paid attention and responded to all of Stella’s gestures, vocalizations, and words, the more she paid attention to and responded to ours. We need to be models for what we’re teaching! Communication is a two way street, and building solid relationships requires us to listen just as much as we talk.
•
This video was from a trip I talked about in my book when Jake convinced me to try letting Stella be off leash for the first time. We didn’t have any treats with us, she was still a puppy, and I had no idea how she would react. To my extremely pleasant surprise, Stella listened and waited when we called out to her! She was intrinsically motivated to stay near us, and had learned that words are important and meaningful. That day was an eye opener for me. It was another example of what can happen when we give someone a chance to learn or try a new skill, and also showed me that the strong communicative relationship we were building with Stella was having significant effects ✨✨
•
#hunger4words #howstellalearnedtotalk #stellabook #presumecompetence #believeinpotential
